action.action-desc: Ms. DelBene (for herself, Mr. Huffman, Mr. Larsen of Washington, Mr. Bowman, Ms. Norton, Mr. Carson, Mr. Levin of Michigan, and Ms. Tlaib) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Natural Resources

form.official-title: To direct the Secretary of the Interior to establish a grant program to assist projects that use nonlethal coexistence measures to reduce property damage caused by beavers, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Developing Alternative Mitigation Systems for Beavers Act or the DAMS for Beavers Act.

subsection.text: Not later than 180 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall establish a grant program under which the Secretary may award grants on a competitive basis to assist projects that use nonlethal coexistence measures to—

paragraph.text: reduce property damage caused by beavers; and
maintain or enhance habitat for beavers and other wildlife.

subsection.text: To be eligible for a grant under the Program, an applicant shall submit to the Secretary an application at such time, in such manner, and containing such information as the Secretary may require, which shall include the following:

paragraph.text: A description of the experience, qualifications, and training (including planned training) of the applicant with respect to the use of nonlethal coexistence measures.

In the case of an application submitted by an applicant other than a State or Tribal wildlife or natural resources management agency (or equivalent), a certification that the applicant has consulted with such an agency (or equivalent).
In the case of an application submitted by an applicant other than the owner of the property on which a relevant proposed project will be located, a certification from such owner that such owner—

subparagraph.text: for the duration of the project, will only allow the use of nonlethal coexistence measures on the property for purposes of reducing property damage caused by beavers (except in the case of a circumstance subject to an exclusion under subsection (d)(2)(A)(i)).

subsection.text: In awarding grants under the Program, the Secretary may give priority to a project that—

paragraph.text: includes monitoring and research that facilitates evaluation of the project and identification of best practices;
is located in an area that ensures grant recipients under the Program represent diverse geographic areas; and
satisfies any other criteria the Secretary determines relevant to effectively reducing damage to property and maintaining or enhancing habitat for beavers and other wildlife.

As a condition of receiving a grant under the Program, for the duration of the project facilitated with grant funds a grant recipient may only use nonlethal coexistence measures for purposes of reducing property damage caused by beavers on the property on which the project will be carried out.

subparagraph.text: Paragraph (1) shall not apply if the Secretary determines that—

clause.text: an activity other than a nonlethal coexistence measure is necessary to protect human health or safety; or
the project assisted with grant funds has been implemented for not less than 1 year and such project has not sufficiently reduced the damage caused by beavers.

subparagraph.text: The Secretary shall maintain a record of each determination made under subparagraph (A).

subsection.text: The Federal share of the cost of a project for which a grant is awarded under the Program may not exceed 75 percent.
Not later than 90 days after the end of each fiscal year for which grants are awarded under the Program, the Secretary shall submit to Congress, and make publicly available, a report that includes—

paragraph.text: a detailed description of the projects funded by grants under the Program;
an evaluation of the effectiveness of the Program in selecting projects according to the priorities described in subsection (c); and
recommendations to improve the effectiveness of the Program.

subsection.text: In this section, the following definitions apply:

subparagraph.text: The term nonlethal coexistence measure means a measure that does not incorporate—

clause.text: the gripping, trapping, injuring, or killing of a beaver;
the destruction or removal of a beaver dam or lodge;
the relocation of a beaver; or
the installation of beaver dam analogues.

subparagraph.text: The term nonlethal coexistence measure may include fencing used to protect culverts, fencing and paint-sand mixtures used to protect trees, and flow management devices used to control water levels in beaver ponds.

paragraph.text: The term Program means the grant program established under subsection (a).
The term Secretary means the Secretary of the Interior, acting through the Director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service.
There is authorized to be appropriated to carry out this section $1,000,000 for each of fiscal years 2023 through 2027.
Not more than 10 percent of the funds made available each fiscal year under paragraph (1) may be used for administrative expenses of the Program.
